questions.text: During which phase of clinical trials is the appropriate dosage range of a drug established?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Phase 1 focuses on evaluating the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of a drug in a small group of healthy volunteers or patients.
  • The primary goal is to determine the drug's safety profile and establish an appropriate dose range.
  • Dosing is initially determined based on preclinical data and adjusted as necessary based on observed effects and tolerability in this phase.

questions.text: Identify the index explained in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic used to rank countries based on human development levels.

  • It is calculated by assessing three key dimensions of human development:
    • Life Expectancy at Birth: Reflects the ability to live a long and healthy life.
    • Education: Measured by the mean years of schooling for adults aged 25 years or more and the expected years of schooling for children entering school.
    • Gross National Income (GNI) per Capita: Reflects the standard of living and economic conditions in a country, adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).

EYS = Expected Year of School; MYS = Mean Year of School

Explanation for other options:

Human Poverty Index (HPI) (Option C): It was developed to measure relative poverty, which refers to the lack of access to the facilities and services that others have. Indicators of HPI are:

  • Longevity: The proportion of people not surviving until the age of 40 years.
  • Knowledge: Adult Literacy Rate
  • Standard of living: No access to safe water supply and sanitation, and % of children underweight.

Multidimensional poverty index (Option D): MDPI complements traditional monetary poverty measures by capturing theacute deprivations in Health, Education, and Living standards. The Human Poverty Index (HPI) was replaced by the MPI in 2010, as it was not specific to any group of people.

Reference:

  1. Human Poverty Index (HPI) and Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) | communitymedicine4all
  2. Poverty threshold - Wikipedia
  3. 2023 Global Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) | Human Development Reports

questions.text: In a population with 500 live births, 12 stillbirths, and 9 deaths occurring within the first 7 days of life, what is the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) is calculated as the number of deaths of live-born infants within the first 7 days of life per 1000 live births.

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) = (No. of deaths of children (neonates) 0 - 28 days of life / live births) x 1000)

questions.text: Identify the importance of given image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The "Sapna" campaign is linked to leprosy awareness in India, symbolising hope and the possibility of a future free from leprosy-related stigma and disease.


Sparsh program:

  • Create awareness about leprosy using Sapna as a mascot
  • Provides prophylaxis to close contacts
  • The concept of Sapna was adopted from Meena. It is for child rights and Impairment gave by UNICEF was successful and adopted by the Leprosy Trust Mission to spread awareness.

Explanation for other options:

Arohi from HIV (Option A): This option may refer to a character or campaign related to HIV awareness, but it is not the correct association for the image related to leprosy.

Meena UNICEF (Option C): The Meena campaign, supported by UNICEF, focuses on gender equality and education for girls in South Asia. It is not related to leprosy or the image in question.

Reference:

  1. Government of India initiative against leprosy, We should be aware - PMC
  2. https://www.unicef.org/bangladesh/en/meena-and-unicef

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines should be kept at the lowest level?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Compared to the other vaccines listed, the OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is kept at the lowest level in Intermediate-Level Refrigerators (ILRs).



Rota (Rotavirus Vaccine) (Option D): The Rotavirus vaccine is sensitive to temperature fluctuations and is generally stored in ILRs at 2°C to 8°C. However, it is often kept at a higher level in the cold chain to ensure stability.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct chronological order of steps in disaster management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Impact: Refers to the immediate consequences of the disaster.
  • Response: Actions taken to address the immediate needs and mitigate further damage.
  • Rehab: Short for rehabilitation, involving recovery efforts and rebuilding.
  • Mitigation: Long-term strategies to reduce the risk of future disasters.

questions.text:
Calculate the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for the year 2023, from the given data:

1. Total women who died: 6
2. Total live births: 4000

Causes of death:
1. 1 due to road traffic accident (RTA)
2. 1 due to sepsis
3. 1 due to obstructed labor
4. 1 due to eclampsia
5. 1 due to ectopic pregnancy
6. 1 due to snake bite
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.

  • Maternal deaths include those caused by complications of pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, excluding accidental or incidental causes.
  • Identifying Maternal Deaths: Maternal deaths: Sepsis, obstructed labour, eclampsia, ectopic pregnancy.
  • Non-maternal deaths: Road traffic accident (RTA), snake bite.

questions.text: What is the correct composition and dosing schedule of the Shanchol vaccine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Shanchol is a bivalent oral cholera vaccine given in 2 doses
  • This refers to a vaccine that targets two different strains of Vibrio cholerae and requires two doses for complete immunisation.
  • The Shanchol vaccine is bivalent, meaning it covers two different strains of Vibrio cholerae (01 and 0139) and typically requires two doses for full protection.

questions.text:
Arrange the following stages of the demographic cycle in the correct chronological order:
1. Early expanding
2. High stationary
3. Late expanding
4. Low stationary
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the demographic transition model, a country goes through 5 phases.

questions.text: Which indicator is defined by a formula that uses the number of maternal deaths as the numerator and the total number of women of reproductive age as the denominator?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pregnancy-related deaths are counted up to 6 weeks (OR) 42 days postpartum.


Perinatal mortality ratio (Option D): This term is not commonly used. If used, it might be mistaken for the perinatal mortality rate, but it does not apply to maternal deaths or reproductive-age women.

questions.text: In a study examining the relationship between diet and disease incidence, 80 out of 200 vegetarians and 100 out of 200 non-vegetarians were found to have the disease. Which statistical test is most appropriate to assess the association between diet type and disease occurrence?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Chi-Square Test is a non-parametric test used to study the association between two qualitative variables.

Explanation for other options:

Paired t-test (Option A):

  • This test is used to compare the means of two related groups. For example, it could be used to compare pre- and post-treatment measurements in the same subjects.
  • This is not suitable for comparing categorical data (diet type) with disease status.
  • It is more appropriate for continuous variables.

McNemar's Test (Option B):

  • It is used for paired nominal data to determine if there are differences in proportions.
  • It is often used in studies with a matched case-control design or in before-and-after studies where the same subjects are measured twice.
  • This test is not suitable for comparing two independent groups (vegetarian vs. non-vegetarian) in relation to disease status. It is used for paired data rather than independent groups.

Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test (Option D):

  • This test, also known as the Mann-Whitney U test, is used to compare differences between two independent groups on a continuous or ordinal outcome when the data does not assume normal distribution.
  • This is not suitable for categorical variables like diet type and disease status.
  • It is used for comparing continuous or ordinal variables.

Reference:

  1. REVIEW ARTICLE ON PARAMETRIC AND NONPARAMETRIC TESTS

questions.text: Which of the following is not included as a component in the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is an indicator used to measure the quality of life or well-being in a country. Unlike the Human Development Index (HDI), which considers economic factors, the PQLI focuses solely on basic physical needs.

EYS = Expected Year of School; MYS = Mean Year of School

questions.solution: Explanation:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the school health program under Ayushman Bharat?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) tablets are provided weekly, not monthly, under the Ayushman Bharat scheme to prevent anaemia in school-aged children.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an initiative promoting school health.

  • Comprehensive health care for children from birth to 18 years by screening them for birth defects, diseases, deficiencies, and developmental delays (4Ds). (Option B ruled out)
  • Children identified with these conditions receive early intervention and follow-up care provided free of cost, including surgeries.

Anaemia Mukt Bharat - Providing iron and folic acid supplements - under WIFS (Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation) (Option D)

  • 5-9 year children: Weekly 1 IFA - 45 mg. of Fe + 400 mcg. of folic acid, sugar coated - pink colour. Biannual deworming with one tablet of Albendazole 400 mg done during the National Deworming days once in 6 months (10 of Aug and 10 of February of every year)
  • Adolescent boys and girls - weekly 1 IFA - containing 100 mg Fe and 500 mcg of folic acid and biannual deworming with 1 tablet of 400 mg Albendazole. (Option C ruled out)

Menstrual hygiene management: (Option A ruled out)

  • Sanitary pads are provided to girls
  • Usually in rural areas

Nutritional Services:

PM POSHAN (POshan SHAkti Nirman) Scheme

  • Previously called as National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools (Mid-Day Meal Scheme) (Option D)
  • Provides one hot cooked meal (⅓Calories, ½ protein) to school children studying in Classes I-VIII in Government and Government-aided schools. To prevent dropouts.

Reference:

  1. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)
  2. Anaemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) | National Health Mission, Tamil Nadu, Department of Health & Family Welfare, Govt. of Tamil Nadu, India
  3. Operational Guidelines for Weekly IFA Supplementation Programme for the theCommunity-Basedd Intervention Guidelines for Anganwadi Workers
  4. PM Poshan

questions.text: For a disease with incubation period of 5-14 days, what should be the recommended quarantine period?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The quarantine period is determined based on the maximum incubation period of the disease.

  • For a disease with an incubation period of 5-14 days, the longest possible incubation period is 14 days.
  • Quarantining individuals for 14 days ensures that if they were exposed to the infectious agent, symptoms would develop within this timeframe if they were infected.

Incubation period:

  • It is the time between the invasion by an infectious agent and the appearance of the first symptom.
  • During the incubation period, the infectious agent multiplies within the host.
  • Once the agent reaches a sufficient density, it disrupts the host's health equilibrium, leading to overt disease.

The median incubation period is when 50% of cases occur following exposure.

questions.text: What is the term for the interval between the entry of a pathogen into the host and the point at which the host reaches peak infectivity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Generation time refers to the interval of time between the recieving of the infection by the host and the maximal infectivity of that host. It encompasses the entire cycle of infection, transmission, and symptom onset in the context of disease spread.

Incubation Period:

  • The incubation period refers to the time it takes for an individual to develop symptoms after being infected with a pathogen.
  • It begins with exposure to the pathogen and ends with the appearance of recognisable symptoms.

Window Period: (Option C ruled out)

  • The window period is the time between infection and when the infection can be reliably detected by diagnostic tests.
  • The individual may be infectious during this period, but tests might not yet show positive results.
  • This concept is important in screening and testing strategies for infectious diseases.

Median incubation period: (Option B ruled out)

  • The median incubation period is the time for 50% of cases to show symptoms after exposure.

questions.text:
What is the median of the following data set?
Data: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The median is the middle value of an ordered data set. Since there are 8 numbers, the median is the average of the 4th and 5th numbers (4 and 5). Thus, the median is (4+5)/2 = 4.5.

  • The median is calculated by arranging the variables in ascending order and taking up the middle value.
  • This applies when an odd number of variables are given, which is given by
  • The median is given for variables in even numbers by averaging the two middle variables.

Maternal Health Initiatives:

questions.text: Which of the following substances should be eaten to prevent thiamine deficiency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rice and wheat, when consumed in their whole form (i.e., brown rice and whole wheat), provide a better source of thiamine and can help in preventing thiamine deficiency compared to the other options listed.

Thiamine deficiency:

  • The Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine. Therefore, whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritional value than completely polished refined foods.
  • A diet predominantly of polished white rice can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, as
    • Thiamine is lost during the process of milling.
    • It is water soluble; thus, further loss occurs during washing and cooking.
    • Thiamine is also lost if the food is baked with baking soda, e.g. bread and cereals.
    • Thiamine deficiency also occurs in chronic alcoholics (Wernicke's encephalopathy)
  • A deficiency of thiamine leads to
    • Dry beriberi (Peripheral neuritis)
    • Wet beriberi (High-output cardiac failure)
    • Infantile beriberi (Seen in infants 2 - 4 months of age who are breastfed by a thiamine-deficient mother).
    • Wernicke's encephalopathy (Chronic alcoholics): Confusion + ophthalmoplegia + ataxia
  • To prevent thiamine deficiency due to dietary habits, it is advised to
    • Consume parboiled and under-milled rice.
    • Have a well-balanced diet.
    • Reduce alcohol consumption.

Reference:

  1. Risk Assessment of Micronutrient Deficiency in Vegetarian or Vegan Children: Not So Obvious - PMC
  2. Vegetarian and vegan diets: benefits and drawbacks

questions.text: A group of 80 people was studied to assess the effect of diet modification on mean cholesterol levels before and after the intervention. Which statistical test is most appropriate to compare the mean cholesterol levels before and after the diet modification?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The paired t-test is the most appropriate test for comparing the mean cholesterol levels before and after diet modification in the same group of individuals.

  • This test accounts for the fact that the data are paired (pre- and post-diet modification) and assesses whether the mean difference is statistically significant.


Reference:

Review Article On Parametric And Nonparametric Test

questions.text: A man with a history of occasional food intake from outside presents with 4 days of abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia. Which diagnostic test is best to confirm the suspected illness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Blood culture is the most reliable test to confirm the diagnosis in the early stages of typhoid fever, particularly within the first week of illness.
  • Typhoid fever, caused by Salmonella typhi, is suspected due to the patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia (a feature known as "relative bradycardia").

questions.text: A 36-year-old fruit farmer presents with fever, breathing difficulties and neurological complications. He gives a history of spotting a few bats on his farm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus that fruit farmers are particularly at risk of contracting due to its association with fruit bats.

  • It presents with fever, respiratory difficulties, and severe neurological complications, including encephalitis, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Explanation for other options:

Ebola (Option A): Ebola virus primarily causes hemorrhagic fever with symptoms like severe bleeding, multi-organ failure, and shock. While it can present with fever and some neurological complications, respiratory symptoms are not typical, and there is no specific association with fruit farming.

Meningitis (Option B): It causes inflammation of the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord, leading to fever, headache, neck stiffness, and neurological complications. However, respiratory symptoms are uncommon, and the condition is not linked to fruit farming.

Zika (Option D): Zika virus primarily causes mild symptoms like fever, rash, and joint pain, and is more famous for its complications during pregnancy, such as microcephaly in newborns. It does not commonly cause severe respiratory or neurological issues, nor is it specifically associated with fruit farming.

Reference:

  1. Ebola Virus Disease - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. Nipah Virus - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: If words are interpreted differently by the sender and receiver during communication, what type of communication barrier does this represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A cultural barrier occurs when differences in cultural backgrounds, norms, values, or worldviews influence how words, gestures, or messages are interpreted.
  • Certain words, expressions, or concepts might hold different meanings or significance in different cultures, leading to misinterpretation or misunderstanding.

Various barriers to communication for health education

Linguistic (Option B): Linguistic barriers occur when there is a difference in the language spoken by the patient and the healthcare provider. If the misunderstanding is due to language differences or poor comprehension of medical terminology, then the barrier is linguistic. However, since the question suggests that the issue is related to understanding the meaning, and not necessarily the language itself, this is not the primary barrier in this case.

choices.text: Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor's opinion is required
Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother
MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case
MTP can be done after 24 weeks.

questions.text: A female presents with 22 weeks of pregnancy as a result of sexual assault. Which statement is true regarding medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the amended MTP Act, 2021, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks in cases of rape/sexual assault, with the opinion of two doctors.

Explanation for other options:

Timing for MTP:

  • Up to 20 weeks: One doctor's opinion is required.
  • Beyond 20 weeks and less than 24 weeks: Only allowed on therapeutic grounds to save the woman's life and pregnancy caused due to rape (Two doctors' decision). (Option C)
  • Emergency cases: Any registered doctor can terminate if necessary to save the woman's life.
  • Beyond 24 weeks: It is generally not permitted unless severe fetal anomalies are detected that are incompatible with life, or if there is a threat to the mother's life or health. This requires the approval of a medical board. (Option D ruled out)

Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor's opinion is required (Option A): Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, for pregnancies between 20-24 weeks, the opinion of two doctors is required, not just one. This applies to specific categories, including survivors of sexual assault.

Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother (Option B): While protecting the life of the mother is one consideration, MTP can also be performed during this period for other reasons, including if the pregnancy is a result of rape, or if there are significant fetal anomalies, without the need for the condition to be life-threatening to the mother.

References:

  1. Legal Abortion Limit Raised up to 24 Weeks of Gestation for Substantial Foetal Anomalies or for Rape Victims: a Welcome Step for Women and Health Providers in India - PMC

choices.text: Start breastfeeding as early as possible
Cover the baby's head and body
Bathe the baby with warm water
Clear eyes with a sterile swab

questions.text: A mother gives birth in a rural setting attended by a skilled care provider. Which of the following actions is not appropriate as part of immediate newborn care?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is discouraged right after birth. Instead, the focus should be on keeping the baby warm and starting breastfeeding.

Antenatal Care and Skilled Attendance at Birth by ANMs/LHVs/SNs:

  • The Government of India, under its National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) and Reproductive and Child Health (RCH)-II program, is committed to ensuring that all births are attended by skilled healthcare professionals.
  • This applies to both healthcare facilities and community settings.
  • The aim is to provide easy access to emergency care for mothers and newborns, reducing the number of maternal and newborn deaths in the country.

Newborn care by ASHA/skilled care attendant:

  • Place the baby on the mother's abdomen.
  • Look for meconium. If there is none, proceed to dry the baby with a warm towel or a piece of clean cloth. (Do not wipe off the white greasy substance (vernix) covering the baby's body. Vernix helps to protect the baby's skin.)
  • Breastfeeding is to be started as soon as possible after delivery, preferably within 1 hour after birth. (Option A ruled out)
  • Wrap the newborn with a blanket/sheet; ensure to cover the head as well. (Option B ruled out)
  • Avoid bathing the baby on the first day. Delay further on winter days. For small babies, delay bathing till the cord falls off. (Option C)
  • Wipe both eyes (separately) with sterile gauze. (Option D ruled out)

Reference:

  1. Guidelines for Antenatal Care and Skilled Attendance at Birth
  2. https://nihfw.ac.in/Doc/Flipchart%20for%20ASHA.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following given diseases has the maximum portion of the iceberg submerged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Influenza has the maximum submerged portion of the iceberg because a large number of infected individuals may be asymptomatic or exhibit mild symptoms, resulting in underreporting and unrecognised cases. This large reservoir of mild or asymptomatic cases contributes significantly to the spread of the disease.

Iceberg phenomenon of disease:

  • It suggests that some diseases have a significant portion of undiagnosed or asymptomatic cases, while only a small portion is diagnosed and visible.
  • The "tip of the iceberg" denotes diagnosed cases or apparent infections of concern to physicians, where diagnostic tests are applied.
  • The "hidden portion" includes undiagnosed or asymptomatic individuals of concern to epidemiologists, who may appear healthy but harbour the disease's pathogenesis.

questions.text: A mother brings her child with complaints of papular lesions on the extensor surfaces of the skin. The lesions improve following supplementation with vitamins A and C along with essential amino acids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phrynoderma is a manifestation of nutritional deficiency involving Vitamin A, E or essential fatty acids (EFAs), particularlylinoleic acid (an omega-6 fatty acid) and alpha-linolenic acid (an omega-3 fatty acid).

  • These fatty acids are crucial for maintaining the integrity and function of the skin barrier. A deficiency can lead to dry, scaly skin.
  • Characterised by the presence of small, rough, cone-shaped papules (follicular hyperkeratosis) on the skin, typically on the outer surface of the upper arms, thighs, buttocks, and sometimes on the face.
  • Can be asymptomatic or associated with mild itching.

Treatment

  • Intake of foods rich in omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, such as fish, nuts, seeds, and vegetable oils.
  • Treating any underlying conditions contributing to malabsorption or dietary restrictions.
  • Emollients and moisturisers.

Explanation for other options:

Rickets (Option B): This is a condition resulting from vitamin D deficiency, leading to weak and soft bones in children. Symptoms include bone deformities and growth retardation, but it does not typically present with papules on the extensor surfaces.

Kwashiorkor (Option C): This is a form of protein-energy malnutrition characterised by oedema, irritability, and skin changes. It usually involves more generalised symptoms of malnutrition rather than isolated papules that resolve with vitamins and amino acids.

Marasmus (Option D): This is another form of severe malnutrition caused by a deficiency in caloric intake, leading to severe weight loss and muscle wasting. It does not present with papules but rather with severe overall wasting.

Reference:

  1. https://www.google.com/url?q=https://openi.nlm.nih.gov/detailedresult?img%3DPMC2854467_IJO-58-175-g001%26query%3Dphrynoderma%26it%3Dxg%26lic%3Dby%26req%3D4%26npos%3D1&sa=D&source=docs&ust=1725598974523732&usg=AOvVaw2pmVc81oBk4rcdkVUo-YxR

questions.text: A man presented with bilateral swelling of his legs, diarrhoea, and dyspnea. He has a history of consuming mustard oil from a local vendor. Which test should be performed by the health inspector to check for the adulterant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paper chromatography is the most sensitive test for detecting the presence of argemone oil in edible oils. It helps identify the adulterant based on the separation and visualisation of specific components.

Epidemic dropsy:

Methylene Blue Reduction Test (Option C): This test is used to measure the bacterial contamination of milk and is not relevant to detecting oil adulterants.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of PQLI?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is an indicator used to measure the quality of life or well-being in a country. Unlike the Human Development Index (HDI), which considers economic factors, the PQLI focuses solely on basic physical needs.

EYS = Expected Year of School; MYS = Mean Year of School
